initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The reigning champion of a prestigious underwater juggling competition has been disqualified and banned from participating for two years after allegations of unsportsmanlike conduct surfaced.

Russian juggler, Natalia Petrova, 35, was accused of using a sophisticated, waterproof earpiece to receive tips from her coach during the competition, which was held at the Shanghai Aquarium last month.

Although the Underwater Juggling Federation (UJF) was unable to find conclusive evidence to support the cheating claims, they did find Petrova guilty of disrupting the event by releasing a school of exotic fish into the competition pool, causing a delay and disturbing the other participants.

Petrova, who was crowned "Queen of the Depths" after her initial victory, was stripped of her title and will forfeit the $10,000 prize money. The UJF stated that her actions were "unbecoming of a champion" and "undermined the integrity of the sport."

The renowned winner of the esteemed Extreme Ironing World Championship has been stripped of their title and suspended for three years following allegations of unfair advantage and reckless behavior.

British ironing sensation, Reginald Pembly, 42, was accused of utilizing a custom-built, high-pressure steam generator concealed within his ironing board to smooth out wrinkles at an unprecedented rate, giving him an unfair edge over his competitors during the championship held atop Mount Everest last week.

Although the Extreme Ironing Federation (EIF) was unable to uncover concrete evidence to support the cheating allegations, they did find Pembly guilty of endangering the safety of fellow competitors by releasing a swarm of genetically engineered, heat-resistant moths into the competition area, causing a distraction and disrupting the judging process.

Pembly, who was dubbed the "Ironing Icon of the Summit" after his initial victory, will forfeit the $20,000 prize money and have his championship trophy revoked. The EIF stated that his actions were "unbecoming of a champion" and "tarnished the reputation of extreme ironing."

The celebrated champion of the prestigious Underwater Knitting Championship has been disqualified and banned for five years following accusations of deceptive tactics and reckless endangerment.

French knitting sensation, Colette LaFleur, 35, was accused of employing a team of specially trained, oxygen-breathing cats to secretly knit intricate patterns on her behalf during the competition held in the depths of the Mariana Trench last month.

Although the Underwater Knitting Association (UKA) was unable to find concrete proof to support the cheating allegations, they did find LaFleur guilty of putting the lives of fellow competitors at risk by releasing a school of bioluminescent fish into the competition area, causing a dazzling display of light that distracted the judges and disrupted the scoring process.

LaFleur, who was hailed as the "Knitting Queen of the Abyss" after her initial victory, will forfeit the $50,000 prize money and have her championship title revoked. The UKA stated that her actions were "unacceptable for a champion" and "sullied the reputation of underwater knitting."

The renowned virtuoso of the esteemed Intergalactic Pastry Championship has been stripped of her title and suspended for three planetary cycles following allegations of illicit ingredient smuggling and astronomical sabotage.

Galactic baking phenomenon, Zara Starlight, 40, was accused of secretly importing a rare, gravity-defying cream from a black market on a distant moon to give her croissants an unfair advantage in the competition held on the orbiting space station, Nova Haven, last quarter.

Although the Galactic Pastry Federation (GPF) was unable to find conclusive evidence to support the smuggling allegations, they did find Starlight guilty of endangering the entire competition by hacking into the station's gravity simulator, causing a temporary loss of artificial gravity that sent pastries and judges alike floating into chaos.

Starlight, who was crowned the "Cosmic Queen of Cream" after her initial victory, will forfeit the coveted Golden Whisk award and have her championship title revoked. The GPF stated that her actions were "incompatible with the values of intergalactic baking" and "tarnished the reputation of pastry-making in space."

The illustrious Captain Orion Blackwood, celebrated commander of the Galactic Space Exploration Corps, has been relieved of duty and placed on interstellar probation for a period of five stellar years following allegations of unauthorized asteroid mining and celestial chart falsification.

Renowned space navigator, Captain Blackwood, 50, was accused of secretly extracting rare, luminescent minerals from a restricted asteroid field to upgrade his ship's propulsion system, giving him an unfair advantage in the prestigious Galactic Rally Race held in the Andromeda galaxy last year.

Although the Galactic Space Agency (GSA) was unable to find conclusive evidence to support the mining allegations, they did find Blackwood guilty of falsifying his ship's navigation charts, leading to a near-catastrophic collision with a comet that put the entire racing fleet at risk.

Blackwood, who was awarded the coveted Golden Starburst medal after his initial victory, will forfeit the prize and have his navigation records expunged. The GSA stated that his actions were "incompatible with the values of space exploration" and "tarnished the reputation of starship commanders throughout the galaxy."

Renowned culinary artist, Chef Starlight, 45, was accused of secretly incorporating forbidden, flavor-enhancing neurotransmitters into her signature dishes to sway the palates of esteemed food critics, giving her an unfair advantage in the prestigious Galactic Chef's Competition held on the planet Zorvath last season.
